title: 113_hr2574
content: The "Keep Student Loans Affordable Act of 2013" extends the interest rate deadline to July 1, 2014 for student loans. It also includes modifications to required distribution rules for pension plans. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include required distribution rules for pension plans in case of an employee's death before full distribution of their interest. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 now includes rules for distributing an employee's interest in a pension plan within 5 years of their death, with exceptions for eligible designated beneficiaries. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for distributions of an employee's pension plan to eligible designated beneficiaries over their life expectancy, starting within 1 year of the employee's death. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows distributions of an employee's pension plan to eligible designated beneficiaries over their life expectancy, starting within 1 year of the employee's death. For clause (i), the portion in subclause (I) is treated as distributed when distributions begin, with a special rule for surviving spouses of employees. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows distributions of an employee's pension plan to eligible designated beneficiaries over their life expectancy, starting within 1 year of the employee's death. If the surviving spouse dies before distributions begin, the date for distributions to begin shall not be earlier than when the employee would have attained age 70 1/2. The Internal Revenue Code allows distributions of an employee's pension plan to eligible designated beneficiaries over their life expectancy, starting within 1 year of the employee's death. If the surviving spouse dies before distributions begin, the remaining portion must be distributed within 5 years after the death of the beneficiary. The Internal Revenue Code defines a designated beneficiary as an individual chosen by the employee, and an eligible designated beneficiary as someone eligible to receive distributions from the employee's pension plan. Designated beneficiary means a surviving spouse, a child under majority age, or a disabled individual as defined by the Internal Revenue Code. The designated beneficiary is defined as a surviving spouse, a child under majority age, or a disabled individual according to the Internal Revenue Code. A chronically ill individual must meet specific requirements for certification regarding their indefinite period of inability. The designated beneficiary is defined as a surviving spouse, child under majority age, or disabled individual. An individual not more than 10 years younger than the employee may also qualify. Employees becoming 5-percent owners must distribute any remaining portion of their interest within 5 years after reaching majority age to meet the requirements. Employees becoming 5-percent owners after age 70\1/2\ must distribute their interest within 5 years to meet requirements. Effective dates apply to this clause. Employees who become 5-percent owners after age 70\1/2\ must distribute their interest within 5 years to meet requirements. The amendments made by this section apply to distributions with respect to employees who die after December 31, 2013. Employees who become 5-percent owners before 2013 and have not retired by 2014 will be treated as 5-percent owners for distribution purposes under the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by this section apply to designated beneficiaries of employees who die before January 1, 2014, and the designated beneficiary will be treated as an eligible designated beneficiary for distribution purposes under the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by this section do not apply to existing qualified annuity contracts in effect before the enactment of this Act.
